title: Love Travelling? Here's How To Do It Without Harming The Planet
text: Ever planned a quick escape from the city and thought, "Am I being good to the planet while doing this?" You are definitely not the only one. With climate change now part of every conversation, more travellers across India are beginning to care about how they travel, not just where. But here is the thing: being an eco-friendly traveller does not mean trading luxury for leaf plates or skipping your morning coffee. It is about travelling smarter, not harder. A refillable water bottle here, a train ride instead of a flight there, and suddenly you are not just a traveller - you are an eco-traveller who prefers leaving no carbon footprints. And honestly, there is no better place to start than India. From Spiti's mountain villages and Kerala's backwaters to the beaches of Gokarna and the forests of Assam, the country is full of places that welcome sustainable travellers with open arms. Also Read: 12 Eco-Friendly Travel Tips Every Traveller Should Know Tourism is responsible for nearly eight per cent of global carbon emissions, and transport remains the biggest contributor. A single domestic flight can produce more carbon dioxide than some people emit in an entire year. In India, where tourism continues to grow rapidly, the impact is visible everywhere, from plastic waste at beaches to overcrowded hill stations. The good news is that change is already happening. A 2025 report found that India's eco-tourism sector is growing by 20 per cent annually, and around 65 per cent of travellers are willing to pay more for eco-friendly options. The message is clear: people want to travel better. So how can you make a difference? Start small. Even a few conscious changes can transform the way you travel and inspire others to do the same. Photo Credit: UnSplash Yes, flying saves time. But did you know that a short domestic flight can emit up to ten times more carbon dioxide than a train journey on the same route? Trains are not only more eco-friendly; they are also far more enjoyable. Think scenic landscapes, station chai breaks, and conversations with fellow travellers. Try this instead: India generates over 3.5 million tonnes of plastic waste every year, much of it from tourist hubs. Every bottle, cup, and wrapper you throw away can end up polluting rivers or harming wildlife. The fix? Just a few smart swaps can go a long way. Small switches that matter: It is simple, light, and stylish, plus, people might just ask where you got your eco gear from. Also Read: 5 Smart Travel Tips That Are Good For You And The Planet Not all hotels are built the same. While some waste large amounts of energy and water, eco-stays focus on comfort with a conscience. Think solar power, rainwater harvesting, and locally sourced food. Look for: Top picks in India: Pro tip: Check platforms like EcoBnB or Good Travel India for verified sustainable stays. Here is a simple rule: if it travelled far to reach your plate, it is probably not eco-friendly. Imported food and factory-made souvenirs add to carbon emissions through transport and packaging. Eating and shopping locally, on the other hand, keeps your money in the community and your footprint small. What you can do: Why it matters: You will taste authentic flavours, take home meaningful souvenirs, and help sustain local livelihoods. Also Read: 5 Smart Travel Tips That Are Good For You And The Planet Wildlife tourism is booming, but not always in the right way. Elephant rides, tiger selfies, and feeding wild animals may seem harmless but often cause stress and suffering to the creatures you came to admire. Be a responsible explorer: Where to go: Respecting wildlife goes hand in hand with reducing your overall environmental impact. That is where offsetting comes in. Photo Credit: UnSplash Even with the best intentions, some emissions are unavoidable. That is where carbon offsetting helps. By contributing to verified green projects, you can balance out the impact of your travel. How to offset: Also Read: 6 Plastic-Free Destinations That Are Leading the Zero-Waste Travel Trend If you are wondering where to put all these tips into action, India has a growing list of eco-friendly destinations that combine sustainability with natural beauty. High up in the Himalayas, Spiti's community-run homestays and solar-powered villages make it a dream for responsible travellers. Stay at Spiti Ecosphere, trek with local guides, and buy handmade woollens directly from artisans. These tiger reserves balance tourism and conservation beautifully. Stay in eco-lodges that employ locals, reduce waste, and fund anti-poaching efforts. Trade noisy houseboats for solar-powered ones. Many villages around Alleppey now practice organic farming and waste segregation, making it easy to enjoy slow, guilt-free travel. A UNESCO World Heritage Site and home to the one-horned rhino, Kaziranga shows that tourism and conservation can coexist. Local communities here play a vital role in protecting the park's wildlife and ecosystem. Photo Credit: Pexels Now imagine millions of travellers making these same choices. That is how real change begins - one journey at a time. Eco-friendly travel is not about perfection; it is about mindfulness. Every time you refill your bottle, skip a flight, or stay in a homestay, you are casting a vote for the kind of world you want to explore. The best part? Travelling responsibly often leads to richer, more meaningful experiences. You connect more deeply with the people, the food, and the places, and leave with memories that stay with you long after you return home.
